executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency.

The pandemic shut down factories and pushed steel prices up in 2021. Subsequently, consumers returned to the marketplace amid the reopening economy faster than supply chains could recuperate, creating excess demand for hand tools relative to supply. Low interest rates and a tight housing market prompted widespread construction investment, putting more pressure on prices at the onset of the current period. Hand tool manufacturers were not able to take advantage of skyrocketing prices because more sales couldn't completely offset costs from high wages and input prices, namely aluminum. In the last few years, revenue fell at a CAGR of 2.1% to $10.8 billion, including an expected 3.9% decline in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Supply chain disruptions wreaked havoc on hand tool production
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic halted hand tool production abroad and in the US. Imports from China, the largest hand tool importer, began rising as US producers faced factory closures in late 2020 and early 2021. Hand tool manufacturers struggled to compete under high input costs and strict pandemic protocols. Price hikes put enormous pressure on hand tool manufacturers – for example, steel prices shot up around the world in the wake of the pandemic. Companies hiked hand tool prices and ramped up production to take advantage of high price tags. Mass hiring and a labor shortage made wage expenditures another challenge.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Excess demand from companies and households has fizzled under high interest rates
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Supply-side issues created a shortage of hand tools as the economy reopened in 2021. Hand tool prices shot through the roof along with rebounding sales. Many consumers – and companies – had massive pent-up demand that imports couldn't satisfy. Low mortgage rates at the onset of the period and few houses up for sale created outsized demand for homes. Home prices soared and construction companies looked to take advantage, prompting massive hiring campaigns and investment in hand tools. But hand tools faced the same supply shortage as houses at the time, leading to even higher tool prices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Growth in consumer spending will support revenue growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Hand tool manufacturers will encounter limited growth at the onset of the outlook period as the labor market feels the pinch of higher interest rates. The national unemployment rate will rise as it normalizes and pressure household spending on things like hand tools, kitchen utensils and razors. Mortgage rates rise alongside the Fed's interest rate hikes, limiting widespread housing starts and consumers' ability to stock up on home goods like kitchen utensils and home repair tools. However, hand tool manufacturers will encounter rising sales from construction companies in the coming years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A weakening US dollar will boost exports and limit imports, but imports will still dominate domestic demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Like consumers and construction firms, hand tool manufacturers will find it hard to borrow money for capital expenditures to reinvest in their companies due to high interest rates. Factories can't expand as quickly and financing new equipment will cost too much to justify the substantial investment. The US has set out to reduce import competition for critical technologies, like semiconductors. The government will list political allies as key trading partners and restrict China, hand tool manufacturers' most significant trading partner. Hand tool manufacturers will find export opportunities in Mexico and Canada thanks to trade partnerships. Imports from Asian manufacturing powerhouses will continue to satisfy more than one-half of domestic demand because of their price competitiveness.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Hand tool manufacturers use e-commerce platforms to reach more households
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: E-commerce is another avenue for hand tool manufacturers to reach households, enabling companies to rely less on home improvement stores and big-box retailers for sales. However, those stores (along with commercial and professional markets) remain the largest sources of revenue for hand tool manufacturers. Companies can promote brands on their own terms through e-commerce platforms. Anyone can put products up for sale on Amazon, for example, reducing dependence on partnerships with online hardware and home improvement stores like Home Depot.

industry_definition: This industry primarily manufactures hand tools, edge tools and metal blades (e.g. screwdrivers, scrapers, bits and saw blades). The industry also manufactures metal kitchen cookware tools, utensils and cutlery (excluding products made by casting or stamping, without further fabrication).
key_trends: Low-cost imports undercut US hand tool manufacturers' prices.
Many domestic producers target high-quality tool markets, sometimes through exporting abroad.

Expanding product lines has driven some consolidation and merger and acquisition activity. Large hand tool manufacturers acquire smaller competitors and companies producing complementary products to widen revenue opportunities.

market_segmentation.segment: Big-box retailers and home improvement centers
market_segmentation.segment_description: Over the last few years, big-box retailers' and home improvement centers' market share in the Hand Tool and Cutlery Manufacturing industry has climbed. These sellers are now the second-largest market for the industry, having taken market share from other types of retailers and causing many of their competitors to shrink in size or go out of business.

Retailers outside the big-box, online and home improvement categories have lost market share in recent years. Losses stem from the higher relative operating costs associated with smaller sales volumes. The diverse retailers that compose this market segment are better able to compete in specialized or high-end products that big-box merchants do not sell. Examples include specialty tools in bicycle shops or top-of-the-line cutlery sets sold by independent retailers.

market_segmentation.segment: Grocery stores, department stores and pharmacies
market_segmentation.segment_description: Grocery stores, department stores and pharmacies are expected to account for roughly one-fifth of industry revenue in 2024 and make up the smallest market.

Professional and commercial users purchase hand tools directly from manufacturers or through wholesalers, including cutlery sets used by professional chefs, scissors for barbers and hand tools intended for professional mechanics and construction workers. Construction companies and restaurants typically purchase bulk orders of higher-quality hand tools made in the United States. Sales to commercial and professional markets have shrunk in the past few years but still account for more than one-quarter of industry revenue. In addition, commercial and professional markets together make up the largest market for the industry.

products_and_services.product_description: Many companies produce razor blades and razors for personal use. Razor blades and razors are expected to generate roughly one-fifth of revenue in 2024 and are the second-largest segment for the industry.
These tools are used in the assembly, maintenance and repair of cars, bicycles and large engines. Products include wrenches, ratchets, screwdrivers and pliers.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Cutting Tools and Precision Measuring Tools
products_and_services.product_description: Manufacturers produce saw blades for power sawing machines and hand and edge tools. Companies in this industry also make cutting tools and precision measuring tools, including parts for machines and power-driven hand tools, like dies and interchangeable cutting tools.

Metal kitchen cookware, stamped and spun utensils (both excluding and including aluminum), cutlery and flatware (except precious) manufacturing generate a significant amount of sales in this industry. Kitchen utensil manufacturers rely heavily on restaurants purchasing in bulk.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Edge Tools, Saw Blades and Handsaws
products_and_services.product_description: Handsaws are responsible for roughly one-fifth of industry revenue.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Many, though not all, hand tool purchases fall under discretionary spending. Disposable income signals households' ability to pay for discretionary items like hand tools. Growth in per capita disposable income benefits the industry as consumers are better able to afford industry products.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Trade Policy Diverts Trade Share From China to Southeast Asia
international_trade_points.trade_description: China remains the dominant source for imported hand tools for the US. An ongoing trade dispute between China and the US has hampered US imports of metal products from China. The US has strengthened trade policy relations with China's key competitors, Taiwan and Vietnam. Taiwan has a demonstrated ability to produce quality products at lower prices and consistently export to the US. Vietnam has recently stepped up to satisfy a growing share of imports to the US.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Lower Cost of Labor, Proximity and Trade Agreements Spur Imports From Mexico
international_trade_points.trade_description: Mexico typically operates with lower labor costs compared with the US. This enables Mexico to be cost-effective and compete with US manufacturers on the basis of price, leading to an increase in the share of US imports from Mexico. Mexico benefits from proximity, supply chain integration and favorable trade deals with the US. The favorable trade relations resulting from the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) facilitate greater trade among these countries.

international_trade_points.trade_title: US Trade Reinforces Ties With Canada and Mexico
international_trade_points.trade_description: It is estimated that Canada and Mexico combine to account for more than one-half of industry exports in 2024. The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) ensures reduced trade barriers between the US, Canada and Mexico, having replaced NAFTA in 2020. Canada and Mexico import bulk edge, cutting, measuring and mechanics' tools for construction and contracting work. US-made tools hold high value.

international_trade_points.trade_title: US Trade Policy Framework Puts Exports at the Forefront
international_trade_points.trade_description: US trade policy will discourage high trade volumes. Exports to China will fall, diverting market share to other trading partners. An expected weakening of the US dollar will drive up industry exports in the coming years. The US will prefer trade with political allies, including Canada, Mexico and Germany. Any trade disputes with Europe could create barriers between the US and Germany, reducing sales for US hand tool manufacturing companies.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region remains a crucial US manufacturing hub, with the country's biggest automobile companies continuing to employ a large manufacturing workforce. In 2020, manufacturing accounted for 59.0% of jobs in this region, according to Michigan Sea Grant (the University of Michigan/Michigan State). Procter & Gamble Company (P&G) maintains its headquarters in Ohio, and the state also hosts the most locations for kitchen utensils and pot and pan manufacturing. Other significant companies with primary facilities in the Great Lakes include Snap-on Inc., headquartered in Kenosha, Wisconsin.

Ports in the West region of the United States house its gateways to Asia and Mexico, two major trading partners for hand tool manufacturing companies. Imports from Asia compete with domestic companies, while US companies export products to Mexico. In addition, favorable trade conditions between the US and Mexico have enabled Mexico to increase their share of products into the US, which has helped Mexico grow into the fourth-largest source of industry imports.

The Mid-Atlantic region, New York in particular, exports and imports hand tool products from Germany and Canada. It also hosts many downstream consumers, making it attractive for hand tool and cutlery manufacturers to locate in the region. The Mid-Atlantic is home to a significant portion of the US population. The region also boasts a densely populated consumer market full of restaurants, construction companies and high-income households.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Hand tool manufacturers may adhere to voluntary standards at national and international levels. Nationally, the American National Standards Institute provides consensus guidelines to standardize products, services, processes, personnel and systems. Internationally, the International Standards Organization and ASTM International provide quality standards regarding products, services and systems to align specifications worldwide.

In 2021, the Biden administration rolled back many of the metal trade tariffs that had been imposed by the Trump administration in 2018. This eased restrictions on exporting US-made goods to Europe and made European steel and aluminum less expensive for US manufacturers.

basis_points.basis_title: Low-cost imports undercut US hand tool manufacturers' prices
basis_points.basis_description: Low-cost imports undercut US hand tool manufacturers' prices. Many domestic producers target high-quality tool markets, sometimes through exporting abroad.

basis_points.basis_title: Expanding product lines drive consolidation and M&A activity
basis_points.basis_description: Expanding product lines has driven some consolidation and merger and acquisition activity. Large hand tool manufacturers acquire smaller competitors and companies producing complementary products to widen revenue opportunities.

concentration_points.concentration_description: THE WIDE RANGE OF COMPANY SIZES CREATES ACQUISITION

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: High Interest Rates and Protectionist Trade Policy Will Keep Input Prices Elevated
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Steel shapes and forms (excluding castings) represent the single-largest purchase category. Kitchen utensils and pots and pans manufacturing requires significant purchases of metals, especially aluminum. Commodity prices spiked in the wake of the pandemic, pressuring cost structures and reducing profit. Prices have since subsided, but US policy aims to diversify aluminum and metal supply chains away from China, raising the risk of elevated prices.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Machine Repairs and Administrative Costs Keep Companies Running Smoothly
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs include inventory expenses, professional and business fees, insurance expenses, maintenance and repairs, research and development and administrative expenses. Additional costs have risen amid high merger and acquisition activity, which comes with legal fees and administrative costs. Costs in this "other" category have grown over the past few years and account for more than one-third of industry revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Relatively High Wages Prevent US Companies from Competing with Imports
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Hand tool manufacturers struggle to compete with low-priced imports because of high labor intensity. Wage costs in the US far outweigh those of foreign competitors like China and Vietnam. A labor shortage following the pandemic pushed wages higher. Many factories had laid off workers and then had to rehire at a higher cost. In addition, many factories that operated through the pandemic had to provide hazard pay. Despite the industry encountering labor shortages during the period, wage costs as a share of industry revenue have lagged in recent years.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: High Commodity and Wage Costs Squeeze Profit Margins
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Hand tool and cutlery manufacturers' profit has been a story of metal price volatility and tight labor markets. Steel prices exploded following the pandemic, raising input costs for metal hand tools and cutlery. In addition, a labor shortage forced significant wage hikes, especially in factories that laid off and rehired many workers in the same period. Wage and input costs have cooled since 2021. Hand tool manufacturers still struggle to pass on higher product prices to customers amid stiff competition from imports. Profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, has declined in recent years.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Relatively high labor intensity for hand tool manufacturers poses difficulties for US companies. Imports undercut prices because of lower labor costs abroad.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Pandemic-related shortages created price inflation, which was followed by higher interest rates
volatility_points.volatility_description: Product shortages following the COVID-19 pandemic caused severe upside revenue volatility in 2021. High hand tool prices stemmed from a spike in steel prices, supply chain delays, low hand tool production and pent-up demand from households and construction companies. Skyrocketing hand tool prices reflect the overall inflation that swept world markets during the collective pandemic recovery. In response, interest rate hikes to combat inflation have pressured demand, to the detriment of hand tool manufacturing revenue in 2022 and 2023. Revenue is also expected to fall in 2024.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Trade Policy Will Both Help And Hurt Hand Tool Manufacturers
volatility_points.volatility_description: US trade policy had a significant effect on revenue trends in the current period. The trade war between the US and China at the onset of the period taxed aluminum imports, created uncertainty and disrupted the global supply chain – hindering imports in the last few years, despite a strengthening US dollar.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: UNIQUE HAND TOOLS MAKE HOME AND CONSTRUCTION WORK EASIER
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Companies design and manufacture special hand tools in response to workers' needs. Double-sided hammers can have a familiar face but a flatter claw for demolition work. These slight deviations from the typical design enable workers to do more niche tasks with hand tools. For example, to help workers carry heavy wooden panels, companies designed panel carrier hand tools that enable workers to avoid injury and move materials more easily.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Unusual Designs Intrigue Household Consumers Buying Kitchen Utensils
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Pizza cutters and slicers have gone beyond the classic wheeled blade with a handle. Slicers come as mini race cars or scissors to catch potential customers' eyes with unique designs. Kitchen tools like spiral sausage slicers and fruit-shaped dicers add an extra element of creativity to food preparation. Companies generate extra revenue by selling products that function almost the same as core products like kitchen knives.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Companies face competition from rising imports, as foreign competitors offer goods at a better price because of less costly manufacturing operations.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries such as China and Vietnam impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: China, Taiwan and Vietnam comprise the bulk of hand tool imports. These countries have a stringent regulatory environment and can pay their employees less, enabling them to pass on lower costs to customers in the US.

FAQs.question: Has your company located near key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers located near distributors can reduce transportation and shipping costs. These companies earn greater profit and maintain favorable relationships with large downstream customers.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in areas with well-established infrastructure?
FAQs.answer: Larger companies have acquired smaller competitors to expand their geographic presence and product offerings. This has helped companies grab a larger share of the market and decrease per unit manufacturing costs.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers have adopted new technologies that provide greater efficiencies in the use of energy. Despite the high upfront cost, this machinery will save manufacturers money through energy conservation and compliance with environmental regulations.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Companies have invested in equipment that increases automation. Including, machines and robots that can load and unload metal onto molds, lathes and computer numerical control (CNC) machines reduce the need for human labor, making products less expensive to produce.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers face strict environmental regulations, like the Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act. Companies work with trade associations and government agencies, like the Environmental Protection Agency, to stay up to date with regulations.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Companies work with trade associations and other groups, such as the American National Standards Institute, to ensure all facilities and products meet federal and state occupational health and safety codes.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Average profit has fallen amid strong price-based competition from internal competitors and foreign manufacturers.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Large companies benefit from exclusive contracts from large wholesalers and retailers, such as Walmart Inc., Target Corporation and the Home Depot Inc. Small operators typically distribute to local retailers. Establishing strong relationships with these key markets helps to secure long-term business arrangements.
